title: Claudio Circhetta
text:
Claudio Circhetta (born 18 November 1970) is a Swiss former <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="referee%20%28association%20football%29">referee</a>. As a player in the Swiss junior leagues for over 20 years, Circhetta often disagreed with the referees, but instead of criticising them, he became a referee himself in 1988. In 2000, he was promoted to referee matches in the <a href="Swiss%20Super%20League">Swiss Super League</a>, and five years later he became a <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>-listed international official.
His first <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a> appointment was a third round match between <a href="NK%20Vara%C5%BEdin%20%281931%E2%80%932015%29">Varteks</a> and <a href="RC%20Lens">Lens</a> in the <a href="2005%20UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">2005 UEFA Intertoto Cup</a>. The following year, he took charge of his first <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Cup</a> match in the tournament proper (following two qualifying matches), a first round match between <a href="Red%20Star%20Belgrade">Red Star Belgrade</a> and <a href="FC%20Slovan%20Liberec">Slovan Liberec</a>. His first Champions League group stage appointment was a match between <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> and <a href="Villarreal%20CF">Villarreal</a> on 10 December 2008. His most prestigious appointment was as fourth official in the <a href="2009%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">2009 UEFA Champions League Final</a>, alongside referee <a href="Massimo%20Busacca">Massimo Busacca</a>. He retired at the end of 2010 to take up the position of Swiss referees chief.
